member.name: T:Resco.Drawing.VirtualBitmap
member.summary: Represents the virtual bitmap which is used by the objects to speed up the drawing.

remarks.para: The Windows CE (and thus also Windows Mobile) operating system has a limitation for the process memory consumption. If the process reaches the memory limit of 32 MB, it is not able to allocate the memory anymore despite that there is still a lot of free physical memory. Thus the Bitmap objects allocate their resources in the GWES process which is excluded from this limitation. The disadvantage of this solution is that it is not possible to access the raw bits for these bitmaps.

VirtualBitmap solves this problem by allocating its resource in the shared memory segment which is not included in the process memory limitation. The result is that the process can allocate same space as it was in case of Bitmap but it is possible to access the raw bits what opens a space for drawing routines which can be several times quicker than the standard GDI routines.

The problems described above relate only to WindowsCE 5.0 and later (that covers all the Windows Mobile family up to WM 6.5). The process memory limitation is not applied to WinCE 6.0 and later device. Each process can allocate the memory up to physical memory limitation. Thus the VirtualBitmap behaves differently for these devices - it allocates the bitmap directly in the process memory.

member.name: M:Resco.Drawing.VirtualBitmap.Finalize
member.summary: The VirtualBitmap class destructor. Disposes an VirtualBitmap by calling this.Dispose(false). Destructor method is automatically invoked during garbage collection, unless finalization by the garbage collector has been disabled by a call to the GC.SuppressFinalize method.

member.name: M:Resco.Drawing.VirtualBitmap.Dispose
member.summary: Releases all resources used by the .
member.remarks: Call Dispose when you are finished using the VirtualBitmap. The Dispose method leaves the VirtualBitmap in an unusable state. After calling Dispose, you must release all references to the VirtualBitmap so the garbage collector can reclaim the memory that the VirtualBitmap was occupying. Always call Dispose before you release your last reference to the VirtualBitmap. Otherwise, the resources it is using will not be freed until the garbage collector calls the VirtualBitmap object's Finalize method.

member.name: M:Resco.Drawing.VirtualBitmap.Dispose(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Releases the unmanaged resources used by the and optionally releases the managed resources.
member.param: true to release both managed and unmanaged resources; false to release only unmanaged resources.
member.remarks: This method is called by the public Dispose() method and the method. Dispose() invokes the protected Dispose(Boolean) method with the disposing parameter set to true. Finalize invokes Dispose with disposing set to false.

member.name: M:Resco.Drawing.VirtualBitmap.OnDisposed(System.EventArgs)

member.remarks: The handle returned by this method is owned by this object and it must not be released by calling object. It will be released during the object disposal.

member.name: T:Resco.Drawing.BackBuffer
member.summary: Represents back buffer.
member.remarks: Note: Back buffer is not thread-safe and if more than one use it at same time, the result may be unexpected (means in multiple threads, it does not apply if more controls use it within same thread).

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with specified initial size.

member.name: M:Resco.Drawing.BackBuffer.Finalize
member.summary: The BackBuffer class destructor. Disposes an BackBuffer by calling this.Dispose(false). Destructor method is automatically invoked during garbage collection, unless finalization by the garbage collector has been disabled by a call to the GC.SuppressFinalize method.

member.name: M:Resco.Drawing.BackBuffer.Dispose
member.summary: Releases all resources used by the .
member.remarks: Call Dispose when you are finished using the BackBuffer. The Dispose method leaves the BackBuffer in an unusable state. After calling Dispose, you must release all references to the BackBuffer so the garbage collector can reclaim the memory that the BackBuffer was occupying. Always call Dispose before you release your last reference to the BackBuffer. Otherwise, the resources it is using will not be freed until the garbage collector calls the BackBuffer object's Finalize method.

member.name: M:Resco.Drawing.BackBuffer.Dispose(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Releases the unmanaged resources used by the and optionally releases the managed resources.
member.param: true to release both managed and unmanaged resources; false to release only unmanaged resources.
member.remarks: This method is called by the public Dispose() method and the method. Dispose() invokes the protected Dispose(Boolean) method with the disposing parameter set to true. Finalize invokes Dispose with disposing set to false.

member.name: T:Resco.Drawing.VirtualBackBuffer
member.summary: Represents back buffer based on .

remarks.para: VirtualBackBuffer is an analogy of the class. Unlike the BackBuffer, it uses the object to store the cached image. VirtualBitmap allows the direct access to the image data bits, what allows implementing the quick drawing routines and smooth scrolling.
Note: Back buffer is not thread-safe and if more than one use it at same time, the result may be unexpected (means in multiple threads, it does not apply if more controls use it within same thread).

member.name: T:Resco.Drawing.CircleDraw
member.summary: This class is an extension of the class. It implements a set of methods for drawing simple or alliased circles, filled cirles, partially filled circles and a parts of a circle.
member.remarks: CircleDraw methods achieve an optimal performance in connection with the class. Drawing to the back-buffer may be up to 5 times quicker than drawing to the destination object directly using the GDI primitives. Moreover it reduces the visual effects which are caused by the direct drawing.
